dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Ms. Spanberger (for herself and Mr. Fitzpatrick) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Education and the Workforce

form.official-title: To amend the Keep Kids Fed Act of 2022 to extend additional reimbursement rates for certain child nutrition programs, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Helping Schools Feed Kids Act of 2023.

subsection.text: Section 2(a)(3) of the Keep Kids Fed Act of 2022 (42 U.S.C. 1753 note) is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking the period at the end and inserting and the school year beginning July 2023.

subsection.text: Section 3(a) of the Keep Kids Fed Act of 2022 (42 U.S.C. 1766 note) is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (1), in the heading, by striking for 2022-2023 school year; and

subparagraph.text: by striking the period at the end and inserting and the school year beginning July 2023.

section.header: Research and implementation of report recommendations

subsection.text: The Secretary of Agriculture (in this section referred to as the Secretary) shall, in accordance with subsection (b), research or implement the recommendations contained in the Child Nutrition Reporting Burden Analysis Study (commissioned by the Food and Nutrition Service of the Department of Agriculture pursuant to House Report 114–531).

paragraph.text: implement, on the publicly available website of the Food and Nutrition Service, a user-friendly, single location for all guidance and policy materials provided to States and school food authorities by the Food and Nutrition Service of the Department of Agriculture;
create and submit to Congress a plan to restructure or simplify the school meal eligibility process, including—

clause.text: the impact of using a unified school meal application form; and

the use of census tract data on poverty levels for verification of eligibility under the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act (42 U.S.C. 1751 et seq.) and section 4 of the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 (42 U.S.C. 1773); and

subparagraph.text: recommendations for legislative changes needed to implement such plan;

paragraph.text: create and submit to Congress a plan that includes recommendations for legislative changes that would allow school food authorities that serve fewer than 100 students and residential child care institutions to receive food from the USDA Foods in Schools program (or cash in lieu thereof) without participating in the school lunch program under the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act (42 U.S.C. 1751 et seq.); and
consolidate duplicative information requests across management evaluations and financial management reviews, while ensuring the purposes of both such reviews are met.
